NewWords.WordPhrase: v. take quickly or roughly 一把抓住； 抢；夺
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A bird had snatched up the snake from the ground and then dropped it on to the wires.
e.g. I gave the loose tooth a tug.

NewWords.WordPhrase: become unsteady; fall 失去平衡
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. She swung around, almost losing her balance.

NewWords.WordPhrase: 突然离去，溜走；（飞机）起飞
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The plane eventually took off at 11 o'clock.

NewWords.WordPhrase: with maximum power, energy or noise 全速地；大力地；极响地
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Do you really need the heater on at full blast?
e.g. He stooped to look under the table.

NewWords.WordPhrase: in touch with 与……有接触
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He was in direct contact with the kidnappers.
e.g. As soon as I get through with my work I'll join you.

NewWords.WordPhrase: come out quickly or suddenly 突然出现（或冒出）   pop v. move rapidly and unexpectedly 突然地活动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Suddenly she popped out from behind a bush.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. put furniture in 为（房子）配备家具
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The room was furnished with the simplest essentials: a bed, a chair, and a table.

NewWords.WordPhrase: turn (electric current) on 接通（电源）；打开
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He switched on the light at the wall socket.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. fall in small drops 滴； 滴下
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Water is dripping from that leaky faucet.
e.g. Everyone made a dash for the nearest exit.
e.g. We have a lot in common.
e.g. I caught hold of my glasses before they dropped to the floor.

NewWords.WordPhrase: show good manners; be polite 懂礼貌；讲规矩
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Did Peter behave himself while I was away?

NewWords.WordPhrase: in the back (of) 在……的后部
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Musicians played at the front and rear of the procession.
